My understanding of what a was sale is is: When you try to sell a stock for a loss but buy it back before 30 days then you don't get to take the loss (ever) that is what makes it "a wash". If you sell a stock for a profit either short or long term capital gain you can buy it back immediatly. If it was a long term gain good for you and in re purchasing there is no penalty the clock simply starts over and you need to hold for 1 year again to take long term gain. In other words a "wash sale" applies to taking a loss on a stock but then negating the loss by repurchasing within 30 days. This was to stop people from selling during the last week in the year to lower taxes then repurchasing the same stock right after the new year. Please correct me if I am incorrect and thank you.

Topic.Title: wash sales question ?

Message.Msg: gamblin can you tell me wahat this means? wash sale losses are added to the cost basis of the replacement shares. In this way, the loss is deferred and recouped when the replacement shares are sold. The IRS advises, "If your loss was disallowed because of the wash sale rules, add the disallowed loss to the cost of the new stock or securities.... The result is your basis in the new stock or securities. This adjustment postpones the loss deduction until the disposition of the new stock or securities. Your holding period for the new stock or securities includes the holding period of the stock

Topic.Title: wash sales question ?

Message.Msg: i think you are wrong about carrying over the loss to another stock. If you buy 100 shares of "A" stock for 10.00 (1000.00) and sell all 100 for 8.00 (200.00 loss), but then buy the same stock "A", say 200 shares at 9.00 (1800.00) within 30 days of the sale then your cost basis for those shares is 1800.00 - 200 = 1600.00. That is the only way to carry that loss over if repurchase within 30 days.
